content.description: In certain regions of the country, elk can cause damage to agricultural crops by walking through the fields. One strategy designed to limit elk from crossing a field is to surround the field with a fence. Some elk, however, will still be able to bypass the fence. For a period of one month, the number of elk found crossing a sample of fields with a fence was recorded and used to construct the 95 percent confidence interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 2.9 comma 4.4, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>2.9</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>4.4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for the mean number of elk. Assume that the conditions for inference were checked and verified.
content.question: The interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 2.9 comma 4.4, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>2.9</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>4.4</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> provides convincing statistical evidence for which of the following claims?

choices.label: The mean number of elk to cross a field protected by a fence is 4 per month.
The mean number of elk to cross a field protected by a fence is 2 per month.
The mean number of elk to cross all fields protected by a fence is greater than 2 per month.
The mean number of elk to cross all fields protected by a fence is less than 2 per month.
The mean number of elk to cross all fields protected by a fence is equal to 3.65 per month.

content.answer: The mean number of elk to cross all fields protected by a fence is greater than 2 per month.

topic.text: 7.3: Justifying a Claim About a Population Mean Based on a Confidence Interval

skill.text: Skill 4.D: Justify a claim based on a confidence interval.
